summary: mh, i don’t know why wearing makeup suddenly became a sin. especially since carol isn’t wearing that much makeup in that trailer...
body:
mh, i don’t know why wearing makeup suddenly became a sin. especially since carol isn’t wearing that much makeup in that trailer beside what? lipstick and blush? mascara? valkyrie wore make up (colourful eyeshadow, mascara, eyeliner), nakia wore make up (pink lipstick, eyeshadow, eyeliner), okoye (a warrior!) wore make up (pink lipstick too, eyeshadow, eyeliner - yes even in battle), pepper potts wore make up.. and so on.. why is it suddenly a problem that carol is wearing make up too? she isn’t in battle, we don’t even know the context of the scene, i don’t see why she shouldn’t wear it. is it degrading for a woman to wear makeup? for a woman superhero/warrior? does it make her less efficient? no. 

were the russos trying to make her look attractive to the viewers? i don’t think so, natasha isn’t wearing any, she even has bags under her eyes. 

besides, the one who is wearing too much makeup in that trailer is steve, with all that foundation and those eyebrows? he looks fake

summary: THE T R A I L E R!!!
title: THE T R A I L E R!!!
body:
OKAY. OKAY. OKAY. OKAY I’ve been waiting ALL DAY to scream about it and it’s been so hard trying to focus on studying for midterms fhfhedsskddjdsh. legit I saw it on reddit this morning while I was eating breakfast and I almost choked on my French toast. they just. DROPPED IT OUT OF NOWHERE I LOVE IT

CAN I JUST SAY I absolutely flipped out when they started it with the Iron Man clip, and the VOICEOVER!!!! i’m sobbing aND TONY’S BACK ON EARTH!!! HECK!!!

Also I’m even more confused about the timeline than before (e.g. Nat’s hair), and honestly I love it. I can’t wait to see where they’re gonna take the story! this movie’s gonna totally destroy me lmao

and the END. WITH THAT SHOT OF TONY’S FACE, “whatever it takes.” 

C H I L L S

In conclusion, consider every last one of my crops watered, i’m a mess

Watch the new AVENGERS: ENDGAME trailer now!

About the film
The grave course of events set in motion by Thanos that wiped out half the universe and fractured the Avengers ranks compels the remaining Avengers to take one final stand in Marvel Studios’ grand conclusion to twenty-two films, “Avengers: Endgame.”

Kevin Feige produces “Avengers: Endgame,” and Anthony and Joe Russo…

summary: I find the black, white, and red scene choices for the “big three” Avengers (Tony, Steve, and Thor) very interesting--and I...
body:
I find the black, white, and red scene choices for the “big three” Avengers (Tony, Steve, and Thor) very interesting–and I think indicative of their potential story arcs.

The black-white-red scenes for Tony are: his first flight as Iron Man, when he escapes from the cave; Pepper’s gift to Tony–the first RT node–”Proof that Tony Stark Has a Heart”; and then Pepper touching her forehead to one of Tony’s Iron Man helmets after their house fell into the ocean in Iron Man 3. Tony’s scenes are to a voice-over of Tony talking to Pepper, musing over all the time that has passed and how much he loves her. 

The themes here are: survival (Tony escaping from the cave), Tony’s emotional core–his heart–which is what gives him his power, and his relationship with Pepper (arguably his future and also connected to the motif of his “heart”). It’s very positive imagery in a way–the connection to heart/love/future. All powerful motivators and possibly the engines that will keep Tony moving after suffering such tragedy. 

The black-white-red scenes for Steve are: Steve back in 1940, when he was skinny, looking into the recruitment office window, seeing his reflection in the uniform. Then, later, Steve carrying Peggy Carter’s coffin in Civil War. Steve’s scenes are to a voice-over of Peggy from The Winter Soldier. 

The themes here are definitely connected to Steve’s desire to do the right thing. He wanted to join the war effort because he strongly believed in the cause–and Steve has never been a man to stand down. It’s also a scene from his past–before he was Steve Rogers–showing he was always a hero (even before the serum). The Peggy voice-over plus funeral scene shows that it’s possible Steve still hasn’t completely let go from his yearning for the past–especially since Peggy is telling Steve in the voice-over that sometimes it’s best to start over (but Steve doesn’t want to start over as indicated by his “But not us” line in the trailer). 

The black-white-red scene for Thor are: Thor and Odin back in Asgard, and then Thor watching with horror as everyone turns into ash after Thanos snapped his fingers. The voice-over is Thor’s horror at seeing everyone die. 

The themes here are very strongly tied to Thor’s loyalty to his people (the scenes of Asgard) and also to his lineage (Odin). We’re reminded Thor is a King. A ruler. But also we see Thor’s strong guilt–and he’s the only one associated with the actual snap event, which could be a connection in some way to Thor’s connections to Death/the Underworld (Helheim/Valhalla). 

Boiled down, it looks like: 

Tony’s thematic is his heart. His strength is his resolve, and then there’s Pepper as his emotional anchor and guiding light toward the future.

Steve’s thematic is his morality. His strength is his burning desire to fight the good fight–no matter the cost. But he’s also weighed down heavily by his lamentations over what he’s lost in the past.

Thor’s thematic is home–Asgard–and also family. His strength is his determination. He’s going to wrestle with his guilt over not going for Thanos’s head, and will work tirelessly to bring the dead back to life.

I find the black, white, and red scene choices for the “big three” Avengers (Tony, Steve, and Thor) very interesting–and I think indicative of their potential story arcs.

The black-white-red scenes for Tony are: his first flight as Iron Man, when he escapes from the cave; Pepper’s gift to Tony–the first RT node–”Proof that Tony Stark Has a Heart”; and then Pepper touching her forehead to one of Tony’s Iron Man helmets after their house fell into the ocean in Iron Man 3. Tony’s scenes are to a voice-over of Tony talking to Pepper, musing over all the time that has passed and how much he loves her. 

The themes here are: survival (Tony escaping from the cave), Tony’s emotional core–his heart–which is what gives him his power, and his relationship with Pepper (arguably his future and also connected to the motif of his “heart”). It’s very positive imagery in a way–the connection to heart/love/future. All powerful motivators and possibly the engines that will keep Tony moving after suffering such tragedy. 

The black-white-red scenes for Steve are: Steve back in 1940, when he was skinny, looking into the recruitment office window, seeing his reflection in the uniform. Then, later, Steve carrying Peggy Carter’s coffin in Civil War. Steve’s scenes are to a voice-over of Peggy from The Winter Soldier. 

The themes here are definitely connected to Steve’s desire to do the right thing. He wanted to join the war effort because he strongly believed in the cause–and Steve has never been a man to stand down. It’s also a scene from his past–before he was Steve Rogers–showing he was always a hero (even before the serum). The Peggy voice-over plus funeral scene shows that it’s possible Steve still hasn’t completely let go from his yearning for the past–especially since Peggy is telling Steve in the voice-over that sometimes it’s best to start over (but Steve doesn’t want to start over as indicated by his “But not us” line in the trailer). 

The black-white-red scene for Thor are: Thor and Odin back in Asgard, and then Thor watching with horror as everyone turns into ash after Thanos snapped his fingers. The voice-over is Thor’s horror at seeing everyone die. 

The themes here are very strongly tied to Thor’s loyalty to his people (the scenes of Asgard) and also to his lineage (Odin). We’re reminded Thor is a King. A ruler. But also we see Thor’s strong guilt–and he’s the only one associated with the actual snap event, which could be a connection in some way to Thor’s connections to Death/the Underworld (Helheim/Valhalla). 

Boiled down, it looks like: 

Tony’s thematic is his heart. His strength is his resolve, and then there’s Pepper as his emotional anchor and guiding light toward the future.

Steve’s thematic is his morality. His strength is his burning desire to fight the good fight–no matter the cost. But he’s also weighed down heavily by his lamentations over what he’s lost in the past.

Thor’s thematic is home–Asgard–and also family. His strength is his determination. He’s going to wrestle with his guilt over not going for Thanos’s head, and will work tirelessly to bring the dead back to life.
